Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: The regular backup is away, so most congregants expect him to step forward for the scheduled prayer.
Story:
I sat on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, staring at the last message from Layla. We’d argued again—this time about how I’d spent money on a new suit for Friday prayers instead of saving for our trip. She wanted to talk, to resolve things before the tension grew any worse. I knew I should go to her, listen, and try to make things right. That’s what a good boyfriend does: he doesn’t let problems fester.

But then my phone buzzed with a message from the mosque committee. The regular backup imam was out sick, and everyone was expecting me to lead Maghrib prayer tonight. The congregation would be waiting, looking to me for guidance and stability. As imam, I couldn’t let them down, not when the community needed me most.

My heart pounded as I weighed the phone in my hand. Layla’s words echoed in my mind, full of hurt and frustration, while the image of the waiting congregation pressed on my conscience. I felt pulled in two directions, each role demanding my presence, each expecting me to put them first. I closed my eyes, feeling the pressure build, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
